page.title: 07Melchbourne Village Hall
page.content: The village hall plays an important role in the life of Melchbourne, being the only public meeting place apart from the church. The original hall was a wooden building that burnt down in 1960. During the 2nd War it was used as the mess for Americans billeted at Melchbourne Park. There still remains the concrete path, that was constructed so that the men did not get muddy feet. The present hall was built with remaining Amenities Money from the 1st War and was designed by an architect who used to live in the village. The hall is used for many functions; parish council meetings, the harvest supper, parties, rummage sales and for half an hour each week as the village post office. Villagers run the hall.
